metadata.disclaimer: Based on publicly available crosswalks and expert analysis. Incorporates new SP 800-53 Rev 5 controls where they genuinely improve coverage. Validate with qualified assessors for compliance/audit use.

clauses.title: Identify important business services
clauses.rationale: PM-11 mission/business process; PM-08 critical infrastructure; CP-02 contingency planning identifies critical functions. CM-12 (new in Rev 5) information location identifies where information assets reside, supporting IBS mapping. CM-13 (new in Rev 5) data action mapping documents data flows underpinning business services. RA-09 (new in Rev 5) criticality analysis identifies critical components supporting important business services.
clauses.gaps: CM-12/CM-13/RA-09 improve identification and mapping of critical services. However, PRA 'important business service' methodology and impact tolerance setting remain UK-specific regulatory concepts not directly addressed by SP 800-53.

clauses.title: Set impact tolerances for important business services
clauses.rationale: CP-02 includes RTO/RPO which are related concepts; PM-11 mission process definition.
clauses.gaps: Significant gap. PRA impact tolerances are a specific UK regulatory concept measuring maximum tolerable disruption. SP 800-53 uses RTO/RPO which are related but distinct. No new Rev 5 controls address this regulatory-specific concept.

clauses.title: Map important business services
clauses.rationale: PM-11 mission processes; PL-08 security architecture; CM-08 inventory; SA-09 external dependencies. CM-12 (new in Rev 5) information location and CM-13 (new in Rev 5) data action mapping significantly improve resource mapping capabilities by documenting where information resides and how data flows through systems.
clauses.gaps: CM-12/CM-13 close a material gap by enabling data-centric resource mapping. PRA requires mapping of all resources (people, technology, facilities, information, third parties) supporting each IBS. People and facilities mapping remain gaps.

clauses.title: Scenario testing
clauses.rationale: CP-04 contingency testing; IR-03 incident response testing; PM-14 testing/exercises; CA-08 penetration testing.
clauses.gaps: PRA requires severe but plausible scenario testing against impact tolerances. SP 800-53 covers security testing but the specific PRA scenario testing methodology and impact tolerance validation are not addressed. No new Rev 5 controls materially improve this.

clauses.title: Lessons learned and actions
clauses.rationale: IR-03 post-incident review; CA-05 POA&M for remediation; PM-06 performance measurement. AT-06 (new in Rev 5) training feedback enables measurement of improvement actions from lessons learned, supporting continuous improvement cycles.
clauses.gaps: AT-06 strengthens the improvement cycle by measuring effectiveness of corrective actions. PRA-specific improvement cycle tied to impact tolerance achievement still needs supplementation.

clauses.title: Outsourcing and third party risk management
clauses.rationale: SA-04 acquisition; SA-09 external services; SR family supply chain. SA-21 (new in Rev 5) developer screening adds personnel vetting for outsourced service providers.
clauses.gaps: SA-21 improves third-party personnel assurance. PRA/FCA outsourcing requirements include materiality assessment, intra-group arrangements, and sub-outsourcing chains which are UK-specific regulatory requirements not addressed by SP 800-53.

clauses.title: Operational resilience
clauses.rationale: CP and IR families cover contingency and incident response. SC-24 (new in Rev 5) fail in known state ensures systems preserve security during failures. SI-17 (new in Rev 5) fail-safe procedures provide additional failure handling for operational resilience.
clauses.gaps: SC-24/SI-17 add resilience depth through failure mode management. FCA operational resilience extends beyond IT to people, premises, and processes. SP 800-53 focuses on IT/information security; broader operational resilience framework gaps persist.

clauses.title: Cyber insurance and stress testing
clauses.rationale: PM-09 risk management strategy; RA-03 risk assessment; CP-02 contingency planning. RA-07 (new in Rev 5) risk response provides risk treatment options including transfer (insurance) and acceptance.
clauses.gaps: RA-07 partially addresses cyber insurance through risk transfer concept. However, PRA cyber underwriting and stress testing requirements are UK financial regulatory specific. Financial regulatory stress testing is fundamentally outside SP 800-53 scope.

clauses.title: Threat intelligence-led penetration testing
clauses.rationale: CA-08 penetration testing; CA-08(1) independent agent; RA-10 threat hunting; PM-16 threat awareness. SC-26 (new in Rev 5) honeypots provide deception technology relevant to CBEST threat simulation. SC-35 (new in Rev 5) honeyclients enable detection of client-side attack vectors used in CBEST scenarios.
clauses.gaps: SC-26/SC-35 add deception technology capabilities aligned with CBEST threat simulation. However, CBEST requires threat intelligence-led red team testing of critical financial infrastructure with specific methodology and financial sector focus not addressed by SP 800-53.

clauses.title: Senior management responsibilities for cyber
clauses.rationale: PM-01 security program; PM-02 senior security role. PS-09 (new in Rev 5) position descriptions formalizes security responsibilities in organizational roles.
clauses.gaps: PS-09 improves role definition. FCA senior management arrangements require specific accountability under SM&CR (Senior Managers and Certification Regime). UK-specific senior manager accountability framework is regulatory and not addressed by SP 800-53.
